channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Do You Live in Germany? Are You a Recent Migrant? We Want to Hear From You
item.description: The Times is hoping to hear from both longtime German residents and recent arrivals about the impact of the recent migration.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees arriving at the main train station in Dortmund, Germany, last year.

item.title: World Briefing: Bolivia: Demonstrators Set Deadly Fire
item.description: Six city workers died and 28 people were injured in a protest after a march by residents demanding better schools and more teachers.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Kosovo: Protesters Rebuke Government
item.description: Thousands of opposition supporters called for the government to resign Wednesday, accusing it of violating the Constitution in deals with Serbia and Montenegro.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Colombia: Chief of Police Steps Down
item.description: The chief, Gen. Rodolfo Palomino, resigned Wednesday amid accusations of illegal enrichment and sexual misconduct with young cadets.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Austria: Limits on Migrants Imposed
item.description: The Interior Ministry said Wednesday that it would allow no more than 80 migrants a day to apply for asylum at southern border crossing points.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Andrzej Zulawski, Rebellious Film Director, Dies at 75
item.description: Mr. Zulawski, known primarily to a small art-house and film festival audience, made no concessions to logic, ordinary human motivations or audience squeamishness.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:description: Andrzej Zulawski in 1985 with Sophie Marceau, who appeared in his films and with whom he had a long-term relationship.

item.title: Editorial: Pope Francis at the Border
item.description: Where Francis shows love, Republican candidates for president would stoke fear.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: Pope Francis ended his visit to Mexico at a prison in Ciudad Jaurez.

item.title: Pope Francis Wades Into U.S. Immigration Morass With Border Trip
item.description: Stepping to the concrete edge of the Rio Grande, Francis on Wednesday went to a militarized divide of the United States-Mexican border and prayed for compassion toward immigrants.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Pope Francis as he arrived for a Mass in Ciudad Juárez on Wednesday, the final day of his visit to Mexico. The Mass was carried live in El Paso, Tex.

item.title: Car Bomb Strikes Military Convoy in Ankara, Killing 28, Officials Say
item.description: The bomb exploded close to the Parliament headquarters and other government buildings in the Turkish capital.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Chinese Missiles on Disputed Island Underscore Growing Conflict Risk
item.description: A day after leaders from Southeast Asian countries gathered in California, a United States official said China had placed missile batteries on an island claimed by Vietnam and Taiwan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Satellite images show a part of Woody Island in the Paracel chain in the South China Sea on Feb. 3, left, and on Sunday, right.

item.title: Venezuela Devalues Currency and Raises Price of Gasoline
item.description: Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro, on Wednesday devalued the currency by 37 percent and raised fuel prices for the first time in 17 years.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Pope’s Presence Crosses Border Into U.S., Even if He Doesn’t
item.description: In Mexico, Ciudad Juárez was naturally consumed with the visit by Pope Francis on Wednesday. But across the border, El Paso was equally swept up.
item.dc:creator: MANNY FERNANDEZ
item.media:description: Women handed out water and prayer cards to pilgrims crossing the border at the Cordova International Bridge in El Paso on Tuesday.

item.title: As Demographics in Cambodia Shift, Youth Seek Political Change
item.description: Two-thirds of the population is under 30, and that generation has outgrown the authoritarian style and patronage system of Prime Minister Hun Sen.
item.dc:creator: JULIA WALLACE
item.media:credit: Luc Forsyth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Traffic passing the Senate building in Cambodia. The country has been stuck in roughly the same political cycle for decades.

item.title: Pope Francis Visits Juárez, Mexico
item.description: Francis is jumping into the heated political debate over immigration. Follow The Times for highlights and analysis of this hugely symbolic moment.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Aid Deliveries Begin to 5 Besieged Syrian Towns
item.description: The deliveries by truck convoys amounted to the first significant benefit to afflicted civilians trapped for months by war.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Rebel fighters on Wednesday escorted a Syrian Arab Red Crescent aid convoy heading toward the villages of Fouaa and Kfarya in Idlib Province.

item.title: Argentina Battles Major Outbreak of Dengue as Mosquito Population Swells
item.description: The authorities said that two provinces had been hit especially hard by dengue, and that the outbreak — the worst in seven years — had not yet peaked.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: A fumigation squad in Buenos Aires last month. Argentina reported nearly 4,900 cases of dengue in the first five weeks of 2016.

item.title: Russia Sues Ukraine in London Court Over Unpaid Debt Claim
item.description: The Russian finance ministry says it is owed $3 billion, escalating a legal battle between the countries that is already raging in European courts.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Spanish Unit of China’s ICBC Raided in Money Laundering Case
item.description: The Madrid branch of the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China is accused of helping Chinese and Spanish criminal syndicates commit financial fraud.
item.category: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Bombardier to Cut 7,000 Jobs as New Airliner Struggles to Draw Buyers
item.description: The Canadian company said that Air Canada had agreed to buy up to 75 of its new airliners, after a prolonged drought in sales announcements.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Paul Chiasson/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Alain Bellemare, left, chief of Bombardier, with Calin Rovinescu, his counterpart at Air Canada, which has agreed to buy 45 jets.

item.title: Infighting Could Dilute British Lawmakers’ Push to Leave the E.U.
item.description: A referendum on Britain leaving the European Union is likely to be held in June, but the inability to coalesce around a single message or leader is complicating the euroskeptics’ case.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, leader of the the U.K. Independence Party, speaks during an event promoting Britain’s exit from the European Union in Kettering, England, in January.
